definition: Deng Tuo (1912-1966), sociologist and journalist, died under persecution at the start of the Cultural Revolution/wrote under the pen name Ma Nancun 馬南邨|马南邨
surname Deng
to expand/to push sth with the hand/to develop/to open up
to make a rubbing (e.g. of an inscription)
surname Tuo
Liao Mosha (1907-1990), journalist and communist propagandist, severely criticized and imprisoned for 10 years during the Cultural Revolution
Kang Sheng (1896-1975), Chinese communist leader, a politburo member during the Cultural Revolution and posthumously blamed for some of its excesses
Xiao Qian (1910-1999), Mongolian-born, Cambridge-educated journalist active during Second World War in Europe, subsequently famous author and translator
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Mao Dun (1896-1981), Chinese novelist
Wu Han (1909-1969), historian, author of biography of Zhu Yuanzhang 朱元璋, hounded to his death together with several members of his family during the cultural revolution
Peng Zhen (1902-1997), Chinese communist leader
Shao Piaoping (1884-1926), pioneer of journalism and founder of newspaper Beijing Press 京報|京报, executed in 1926 by warlord Zhang Zuolin 張作霖|张作霖
Chen Boda (1904-1989), communist party theorist, interpreter of Maoism
Bo Yibo (1908-2007), ranking PRC politician, served on State Council from 1950s to 1980s as colleague of Deng Xiaoping
Xia Yan (1900-1995), Chinese writer, playwright, socialist critic and movie pioneer
Cao Jinghua (1897-1987), translator from Russian, professor of Peking University and essayist
Zhang Wentian (1900-1976), CCP party leader and theorist
Guo Moruo (1892-1978), writer, communist party intellectual and cultural apparatchik
Hu Yaobang (1915-1989), Chinese politician
Chen Yi (1901-1972), communist general and politician, Marshal of PLA from 1955, Mayor of Shanghai in 1950s, PRC foreign minister 1958-1972
